newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Panic hits Jakarta as high-rises sway in quake.
newsitem.headline: Panic hits Jakarta as high-rises sway in quake.

text.p: A strong earthquake rocked the Indonesian capital Jakarta on Monday afternoon, sending people scurrying out of high-rise buildings.
There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties.

Officials at the meteorological department said the earthquake was centred below the sea-bed in the Indian Ocean, some 300 km (200 miles) southwest of the teeming metropolis, home to about 10 million people.
It measured 6.0 on the Richter scale.
"This is the biggest earthquake to have hit Jakarta in recent times," Taufik Rivai, head of the geophysics section in the meteorological department, told the official Antara news agency.
"It was just lucky, the epicentre was in the Indian Ocean, and we only felt the tremors. If the quake happened on land, it would have been enough to destroy buildings," Rivai said.
Police in the coastal towns of West Java province facing out towards the epicentre said they had felt the earthquake but reported no damage or tidal waves.
"The cars moved in the street, but there was no damage," a policeman on duty in the coastal town of Labuhan told Reuters by telephone. "There was no tidal wave," he added.
Antara said the earthquake was felt throughout West Java as well as in Lampung province on Sumatra and in Palembang, the capital of South Sumatra province.

Tall buildings in Jakarta shook when the tremor hit the city at about 3:10 p.m. (0810 GMT) and people rushed out onto the street. Building managers used public address systems urging people not to panic.
Traders fled the stock exchange, brokers said, but returned after about half an hour. The exchange was not officially closed despite the panic.
"There were lots of traffic jams in the business district because all the people in those tall office buildings came out on the street," said one witness.
"Things were really swaying out here," said a guest staying in an upper floor of the Mandarin Oriental Hotel. He said people rushed out of the building but there was no damage.
Other witnesses said many workers left their offices early as rumours spread of possible aftershocks.
However, Rivai said while aftershocks would continue, they would be of a magnitude which would not be felt by people.
The Indonesian archipelago, located on the edge of the geologically unstable zone known as the "ring of fire", is earthquake prone.
